title: 113_s2352
content: The Act titled "Russian Weapons Embargo Act of 2014" prohibits the use of funds to enter into contracts with ROSOBORONEXPORT. The "Russian Weapons Embargo Act of 2014" prohibits executive agencies from entering into contracts with Rosoboronexport or its affiliates for military equipment, requiring immediate termination of existing agreements. The President has the authority to waive this prohibition for national security reasons. The President can waive the prohibition on contracts with Rosoboronexport if certain conditions are met, including the cessation of military equipment transfers to Syria, Russian forces withdrawing from Crimea, and no active measures by Russian agents to destabilize governments. The President may reprogram funds for countries that support efforts to destabilize Ukraine, specifically by engaging with Rosoboronexport or its affiliates. The President must notify Congress before reprogramming funds for countries involved in destabilizing Ukraine. Definitions include "appropriate congressional committees" and "executive agency." SEC. 3. REPORT ON ROSOBORONEXPORT ACTIVITIES. The Secretary of Defense must report to Congress within 180 days of this Act on Rosoboronexport's transfers of military equipment to Syria since March 15, 2011, contracts with Syria since that date, and all Department of Defense contracts with Rosoboronexport. The Secretary of Defense must report to Congress within 180 days on Rosoboronexport's transfers of military equipment to Syria since March 15, 2011, contracts with Syria since that date, and all Department of Defense contracts with Rosoboronexport in unclassified form, with the possibility of a classified annex. The term "congressional defense committees" is defined as in section 101(a)(16) of title 10, United States Code.
